title: Posterior Inference Methods
description: Posterior inference involves computing or approximating the posterior distribution of parameters given observed data, central to Bayesian statistical analysis.
learning_objectives: Understand different approaches to posterior inference
Compare exact and approximate inference methods
Implement posterior inference for practical problems
Connect posterior inference to Active Inference

content.overview: Posterior inference is the process of computing the posterior distribution P(θ|D) that represents updated beliefs about unknown parameters θ given observed data D. This is fundamental to Bayesian analysis but often computationally challenging for complex models.

exact_inference_methods.conjugate_priors: Closed-form posteriors when likelihood and prior are conjugate
exact_inference_methods.matrix_operations: Linear algebra solutions for Gaussian models
exact_inference_methods.recursive_methods: Sequential updating for time series models

approximate_inference_methods.markov_chain_monte_carlo: Sample from posterior using Markov chains

monte_carlo_methods.metropolis_hastings: Markov chain sampling with acceptance ratio
